Colin, thanks for sharing this article with the group.  It is indeed inte=
resting, but I was left wishing it had spoken more about how the network ac=
tually works (i.e. as some kind of sensor processing system), rather than j=
ust how it becomes connected.  The neurons there presumably process the inp=
uts from the sensors, but it is unclear what they are supposed to be doing =
functionally.  Without that information, it's unclear to me whether the obs=
erved strategy is generally useful for forming many different functional AN=
Ns or specific to a certain kind of preliminary processing step with this t=
ype of sensor.  

Of course playing with your idea inside HyperNEAT would b=
e interesting in any case and might provide some insight into the general u=
tility of the process.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Colin Green <coli=
n.green1@...> wrote:
>
> http://www.kurzweilai.net/fruit-fly-nervous-system=
-provides-new-solution-to-fundamental-computer-network-problem
> 
> This is=
 interesting from a developmental encoding point of view,
> specifically wi=
th respect to the latest hyperneat work around
> placement of neurons.
> 
>=
 My hyperneat take on this idea would be to produce a bunch of
> 'speculati=
ve' neurons in the substrate with varying density based on
> querying the C=
PPN. Then place a random timer in each neuron, when a
> timer fires that ne=
uron becomes a real neuron and tells surrounding
> neurons not to fire. I a=
ppreciate it puts time back into the
> developmental process, which could s=
low things down (one of the wins
> of CPPNs was the elimination of iterativ=
e developmental processes).
> 
> Regards,
> 
> Colin
>
